madihashafqat: As a college student, one of my biggest concerns is paying for college. n.amuses: Choosing a major/career path. Money over what I love or vis versa? Is it possible to have both? With what career? I don’t have mommy and daddy’s money to cover me financially in and after college if my career falls short. The people who always tell me to do what I love are living normal lives/the occasional struggle or are already well-off. The people who are making money hate their jobs, but love the benefits 🤦🏾‍♀️ I don’t know what to do...
differentkindofhumanbeing: I would love to be present !
kate_fiona: This is so cool @elainewelteroth ! I’m super passionate about education as an opportunity opener (and also a dream builder - as you say, if you can’t see or imagine it, you can’t work towards it). I have a job I love these days working in a charity building tech products for vulnerable people. I did a law degree like MO and worked as a lawyer for a while. It wasn’t for me, but I ended up in a place I love anyway. It would be great to ask her how important is it to choose the ‘right’ degree/‘perfect’ course vs how much is it just about learning. When I look back on picking a degree and how much I worried about it I think I worried too much. Doing my degrees was important because it opened my mind and taught me how to think and solve. But I’m not so sure that course choice is always as important as young people think - learn to learn and you’ll be set for life (or something like that)...?

barkuniversity: @gesguzman but I thought this was you 😘
brownskinjalissa: Thank you so much for the inspiring work that you do♥️ As a new 30 year old, it has been a challenge for me emotionally and professionally that I never finished school. As a first generation college attendee and 2nd year student, I ended up losing my scholarship at 20 yo due to struggling grades (bio pre-med), and because my family didn’t have the resources or “know-how” to help me, I had to leave my school, go back home to Chicago and look for work. I am blessed that I found a career in finance and have been pretty successful; however this has always been a dark shadow and a big insecurity for me and has often disabled my career progression. I’ve tried to go back on a few occasions but was defeated by obstacles like existing student loans, affordability, previous grades minimum requirements for application, or work inconvenience. With all of this in mind, I know my story is not uncommon; so my question to you is what is your advice to someone like me?

conqring_lion: Hi Elaine! As an African America woman attending a PWI that has no structural support or diversity office dedicated to supporting the colleges small diverse population, I often find myself struggling, alone, not feeling accepted nor supported. There have been efforts again and again to establish some what of an office or diversity club, but with lack of participants and little membership nothing ever sticks. I know that I am not the only one that feels alone or unaccepted or unsupported at my school and I know that many students in the future even after I'm gone might feel the same way. I want to end this cycle by becoming an agent of change, but with lack of support from the institution and the student body, I feel helpless. Any advice? @elainewelteroth
niccatso: I'm a recent graduate with my Master's (woo!). I'm having the hardest time with the job search process. I have a lot of relevant and extra experience (volunteer work that I cared about, mentoring projects, a thesis, etc), I have networked and dedicated myself to job searching full time, and somehow I am still not being hired. I have made it to the final round of several interview processes, but I keep getting passed over and told that *some company* will really be lucky to have me. How do I convince employers that I'm worth giving a chance to? Furthermore, what is your advice for preventing burnout and getting bogged down in this scenario? Thank you so much @elainewelteroth and @michelleobama!!! 😍❤
splenetique: @elainewelteroth this is such a feel-good story! Knowing what u do will pay off one day is a nice thing. I am also the first who's gone off to study at a uni and it was not easy. I learned a lot about myself and am still learning. What I wanna share is, that to be true to yourself thru your college years is important to find your tribe. I am a woman in tech and soon finishing university and I did experience that there is some bias towards women coding and conceptualizing, especially when u are working in a group with also men. They do not do it intentionally often that they start mansplaining stuff without having asked for their opinion but they do not even think that they might have internalized some biased thinking. So it's good to have your back up, your girls and colleagues who are cool with u being confident. It will help with feeling frustration. Talking bout your thoughts and feelings is also key. And trusting in yourself first can go a long way. And always ask when u wanna know something, be curious. Wish u all all the luck and success to pursue your dreams! And hold on if you are the first one to go studying, u probably might inspire more ppl to do so!
mixitupwithcurves: This is such a great cause! I think that helping high school students of color connect with current college students as mentors would be beneficial. The students I work with often can’t picture themselves in college. It’s not a tradition in their family so there’s a lack of connection to that world. They think it’s for those other kids. Bravo 👏🏾 for your efforts ✨
yoursgabdior: How did you know that you were choosing the right field for yourself and not based off of what others thought you should pursue?
br1tz: What is an important thing to look at or think about when looking for HBCUs to attend?
r.mattea: I'm finishing my degree much later than I expected, for a variety of reasons, and many of my high school friends now hold steady jobs & are having families. What would you say to someone who sometimes feels inadequate because of these things?
itsericat: Hi! I’m 25 and no one in my family graduated from college. I went temporarily to gain my cosmetology license. I love what I do. Seeing you, a woman from my town is incredibly inspiring and brings so much love light to my feed. Thank you 💜
sunbeamnai: As a young black queer creative from a big city like New York, l find it hard to find opportunities that appeal to my interests as a creative person with mental health issues, like bipolar disorder and anxiety to name a few. I’m turning 20 this July, and I’m currently not in college due to mental health reasons, and have dropped out for the 3rd time in 2 years... I’ve found it quiet discouraging to pursue my passions, as an almost 20 year old who hasn’t had any real life experience as far as college and a formal education is the traditional sense. While I was in college and tried to navigate both school and mental health, which became to hard of a task — l felt as though when l expressed my overarching concerns with my bipolar disorder to my college counselors and advisors l felt like the responses to my concerns weren’t heard and neglected — statements like “our college doesn’t take kindly to students like you, who stop and start a semester” or “you’re becoming a statistic” were thrown into many conversations, at the point of this conversation with these staff members and other incidents l was horridly depressed and ended up attempting suicide. After, recovering from that traumatic event, I’ve wanted to pose these questions to Mrs. Obama, “Should colleges have a safe space and support for individuals in college with mental health issues if they are documented by medical records? “How should established institutions like colleges openly address a student with mental health issues when they are asking for help both academically and personally without making the individual feel worse?” and “How can an individual look for resources and find a way to still pursue their passions and dreams if college seems to big of an obstacles?” Thank you both! Naimah

5ocheata: How do you keep in touch with friends after college? Especially when they are all over the world
meghadawer: What type of advice would you give to those students who are looking at an occupation which does not have many entry-level jobs but opportunities for those who have multiple year of experience? should these students keep their options open and study something else as well or just focus on what they are doing and hope for the best?
gordonching: It took me 7 years to graduate and get my bachelors degree. There are 4 years within that where I took an extended leave to pursue career opportunities that changed my life. I was able to work around the world with a global nonprofit @aiesecglobal and eventually at @apple in marketing. These experiences completely shifted my mindset on education moving from a linear to a progressive approach. How do we teach young kids these days that school is not just about mindlessly going through school but to take the chances and opportunities that grow them as an individual. How can we make our education system more flexible and experiential that supports this model? Allowing people to have greater access to learning on both outside and inside classroom experiences? Thank you @elainewelteroth!
synnnnney: Passion and motivation is very important. There is no black and white world where some go to college and become successful and some don’t and become nothing. College is not for everyone, although it is a GREAT starting point for many. There are soooo many programs out there to do after high school than to go college. Everyone learns differently and everyone achieves success differently. I’m a first generation college student in my family, and I realized this once I got to college and moved to a city. Some may feel stranded in your talk about college as being the only solution, when in fact that is not true. One must take their passions and motivate themselves to learn in a way that fits them, whether that be college, a trade, internships, work study. It is very important to reach out to people that are doing what you Want to do, find some mentors and learn. There are many options, and it is VERY important to inform people of that.
mimiandtheunicorns: College is going the way of rotary phones, over time it will become non-essential especially in technology careers where apprenticeship (or a form of it) is more valuable and valued. I welcome this model, crippling college debt should have no place in our society. The only people resisting this change are people who have a college degree and universities that need the income. How can we as minorities and women prepare for that?
alannaorgill: Tips on navigating the first semester of college?
melody8rown: What would you say to a person who is late in the game? Starting college in their 30s
chy.niecem: as I approach my senior year in college I realized that my problems/situations would not be the same in a different environment. I have struggled from point a to b in terms of figuring out what I want to do after I graduate and living in a society that functions to produce more and more of whatever at a pace that creates a deadly amount of anxiety I am strongly considering finishing my education in another country where things like gun violence in a school setting is unheard of, amongst other things. And To that end many college students including my self have lost hope in equal and sustainable opportunity here, and this is just barely scraping the surface
full_oflife1: How did you manage for finances during the school year? A lot of people ask about debt afterwards but there are struggles currently through the year of financial aid and scholarships are still not enough. Asking because I’m in a position where I might not be able to go back to school due to this.
kickitwiththeking: do you have an advice for finding work / battling debt and loan repayment after graduating college?
monigabrii: how do you know that you’ve chosen the right school for you, esp when the choice is between a school that would leave you in major debt but feels like home vs a school that doesn’t yet but gave you...a full ride?
aaliyahsadler: Sacramento, CA - Hello @elainewelteroth💓 I’m still attending a junior college after graduating from high school four years ago. Society puts on a lot of pressure to enter and graduate from college in four years and then pursue a masters degree shortly after. The most successful people in the world never even finished college (Mark Zuckerberg, Bill Gates, Steve Jobs). Do you think you can still be successful in today’s society without a college degree and still be financially comfortable?

csevolutionofstyle: This is incredible! What a blessing of an opportunity to interview the only #FLOTUS i acknowledge @elainewelteroth 😱🙌🏾
mia.baella: Because I am a Latina people make me feel as though I’m attending my school because I’m a minority and as though I’m less deserving or qualified to be a student there. Was this ever something you experienced? If so, how did you counteract it?
tabreshal: How do you think we get people to move past the stigma of community college as the 13th year? I work at a community college in Prince George’s County (a suburb of DC) and I always hear from students who say they never took community colleges seriously, when in fact, it’s a great option to pursue a higher education and reduce the cost of college all together. Especially for low income families who may not be able to afford the expensive costs associated with 4-year universities. Community Colleges can make it so that you only end up paying really expensive tuition for two years verses four. So how do we get people to see that as well as the other benefits of attending a community college to create a better quality of life for themselves and their families?
graffitiface: I am screaming at this last post on ig! I'm Soooo proud of you!!!! I remember you telling me about the beginning and now it's all coming around full circle! Congrats!!! I'll be in dc tomorrow I'd LIVE to just be in the room!!!!!
t2_tasha: So awesome!! So good to see the high school and college kids chiming in on their questions. Love it!!!
_iajai: I'm a junior next year and I feel as if I have no path. I know everyone says we have time but each day it seems like people are expected to be successful younger and younger. Is it actually possible to pursue a dream rather than get by? I don't want to get a useless degree just because I want to be a poet but I surely dont want to get a degree in something I don't like and be miserable. Is it truly possible to have a balance of passion and profession?
terridanyale: I’m a first generation college student, I just recently graduated! It’s an exciting time in my life but also a wee bit discouraging because I worked so hard my entire college career, missing out on things bc of my part time job and internship. I knew for certain my internship would hire me on full time bc I busted my butt. Only they let me go, increased the pay & hours yet told me I did incredible the entire 8 months I was there. My question is how do I stay motivated to follow my dreams when on the job hunt especially after facing a blow like that AND being denied to nearly every position I apply for.

marienoelnt: My parents moved to Austria in the 80s. None of them graduated high school. My brothers and sisters and I are the first in our entire family to go to college and graduate. Which was the reason why my parents left Congo in the first place. So I find this iniative inspiring as well as important. Foremost because everyone should have access to an education but also because you never know where your education can take you guys. Don't take it for granted, but don't be scared to give it a try, to dare to purchase your interests and dreams. 🙌🏾🙌🏾🙌🏾 It wasn't a question per se but I wouldn't be where I am today without my college education. So I just wanted to chip in on this opportunity. 💛❤️💙💚💜🧡 @elainewelteroth
sisstayready: This is so beautiful and a great reminder that those we look up to put in the work for years before they were in front of the camera. Wish I knew how to attend this event. If I could go back I would have found time to do an internship with my Federal Work Study to get more experience in my field of Communications. It's hard when part of your federal assistance is required work that isn't always related to what you want to do. 👏🏾👏🏾
